clinical_study.brief_title: Determinants of the Long-Term Success of Bariatric Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Determinants of the Long-Term Success of Bariatric Surgery "- Multicenter Regional Observational Study: Regional Multicentre Prospective Study

brief_summary.textblock: The management of obesity is based on a multidisciplinary approach and justifies the use of surgery in patients with the most severe forms. Surgery for obesity or bariatric surgery generally allows rapid and significant weight loss however it is associated with significant risks, and its long-term results remain heterogeneous and unpredictable. Long-term data will clarify the role of different types of bariatric surgery in surgical strategy, improve patient information and identify predictors of failure in order to provide personalised and tailored surgery for each candidate .

detailed_description.textblock:
Currently, there is insufficient data to determine the persistence over time of the positive results of bariatric surgery on weight loss. Moreover, there is no consensus or criteria for choosing one surgical weight loss procedure over another. The best choice for one patient may not be the most appropriate for another.
The results of this project will allow to better select obese patients likely to benefit from bariatric surgery, and to further personalise the management of severe obesity.

primary_outcome.measure: Success rate in terms of weight loss
primary_outcome.description: Rate of patients who lost at least 20 of their initial body weight

secondary_outcome.measure: Success rate in terms of weight loss according to type of bariatric surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of patients who lost at least 20 of their initial body weight at 1 year according to type of bariatric surgery (Gastric by-pass in Y or Omega, sleeve gastrectomy, and gastric band)

secondary_outcome.measure: Success rate in terms of weight loss according to type of bariatric surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of patients who lost at least 20 of their initial body weight at 5 years according to type of bariatric surgery (Gastric by-pass in Y or Omega, sleeve gastrectomy, and gastric band)

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of re- interventions related to bariatric surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation of re-interventions following bariatric surgery

study_pop.textblock:
The project relies on the network of Specialised Centres for the Management of Severe Obesity (Lille, Arras, Boulogne, Valenciennes).
Patients with severe obesity who underwent bariatric surgery 5 years ago will be included in each of the centre, during the usual multidisciplinary care visit.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who received bariatric surgery 5 years ago.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Refusal to participate in the study,
- Unable to receive informed information,
- Unable to participate in the study
